elements.content: A systematic study detailing the uptake of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules into the pores of the crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2·x(solvent)} n ] has been performed. The reproducible positioning of the guest molecules within the unit cell has been documented. Analysis of guest–host and guest–guest interactions has shown the dominant role of π···π and CH···π interactions in the ability of the crystalline sponge to render the guest molecules regularly ordered. Further interactions specific to guest functionality, such as weak hydrogen bonds, are seen to contribute to the particular orientation of the guests.
elements.clean_text: A systematic study detailing the uptake of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules into the pores of the crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2⋅x(solvent)} n ] has been performed. The reproducible positioning of the guest molecules within the unit cell has been documented. Analysis of guest-host and guest-guest interactions has shown the dominant role of π⋅⋅⋅π and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the ability of the crystalline sponge to render the guest molecules regularly ordered. Further interactions specific to guest functionality, such as weak hydrogen bonds, are seen to contribute to the particular orientation of the guests.

elements.content: A systematic study detailing the uptake of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules into the pores of the crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2·x(solvent)} n ] is reported. The reproducible positioning of the guest molecules within the unit cell has been shown along with the role of π···π and CH···π interactions and weak hydrogen bonds in rendering the guests regularly ordered.
elements.clean_text: A systematic study detailing the uptake of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules into the pores of the crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2⋅x(solvent)} n ] is reported. The reproducible positioning of the guest molecules within the unit cell has been shown along with the role of π⋅⋅⋅π and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions and weak hydrogen bonds in rendering the guests regularly ordered.

elements.content: In 2013 Fujita and co-workers published a groundbreaking paper introducing a technique that claimed to overcome the inherent limitations of single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). As the premier method for unambiguously determining complete structural information, SCXRD can require significant investment of time and effort (i.e., single crystal growth and selection) and by definition is limited to single crystalsmeaning that structures of liquid and amorphous solids are unobtainable by this method. The solution, “crystal-free crystallography”, was a simple one: encapsulate the noncrystalline compound within a crystalline framework which, through the formation of strong guest–host interactions, may render it regularly ordered and thus capable of contributing to Bragg peaks and a diffraction pattern. It was not the idea of studying a guest enclathrated in a host framework that was novel (small guest molecules have been studied in clathrates and more recently in porous organic materials) but rather the use of specific host materials: metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The most successful MOF for this application has been [{(ZnI2)3(tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2·x(solvent)} n ], which is suitable for use in absolute structural determination via the Bijvoet method because of its heavy-atom content. Implementation of the technique has not been without difficulty, but its applicability has been tested and its value clearly demonstrated.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In 2013 Fujita and co-workers published a groundbreaking paper introducing a technique that claimed to overcome the inherent limitations of single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD). As the premier method for unambiguously determining complete structural information, SCXRD can require significant investment of time and effort (i.e., single crystal growth and selection) and by definition is limited to single crystalsmeaning that structures of liquid and amorphous solids are unobtainable by this method. The solution, "crystal-free crystallography", was a simple one: encapsulate the noncrystalline compound within a crystalline framework which, through the formation of strong guest-host interactions, may render it regularly ordered and thus capable of contributing to Bragg peaks and a diffraction pattern. It was not the idea of studying a guest enclathrated in a host framework that was novel (small guest molecules have been studied in clathrates and more recently in porous organic materials) but rather the use of specific host materials: metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). The most successful MOF for this application has been [{(ZnI2)3(tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2⋅x(solvent)} n ], which is suitable for use in absolute structural determination via the Bijvoet method because of its heavy-atom content. Implementation of the technique has not been without difficulty, but its applicability has been tested and its value clearly demonstrated.

elements.content: The linker utilized for this “crystalline sponge” is the large panel-like molecule tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TPT), a well-established component used in container compounds, three-dimensional networks, and supramolecular chemistry (where the electron-poor heteroaromatic moiety is implicated in key supramolecular interactions, i.e., hydrogen bonds or π interactions). TPT’s high aromaticity and electron deficiency impart an ability to form π···π, CH···π, and charge-transfer interactions with electron-rich molecules. By its incorporation into a MOF structure, most commonly combined with ZnI2, these properties are exploited and enhanced through the creation of “sticky” hydrophobic pores that absorb guest molecules via thermodynamic solvent–guest exchange, allowing equilibration of their positions through the porous framework.
elements.clean_text: The linker utilized for this "crystalline sponge" is the large panel-like molecule tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine (TPT), a well-established component used in container compounds, three-dimensional networks, and supramolecular chemistry (where the electron-poor heteroaromatic moiety is implicated in key supramolecular interactions, i.e., hydrogen bonds or π interactions). TPT's high aromaticity and electron deficiency impart an ability to form π⋅⋅⋅π, CH⋅⋅⋅π, and charge-transfer interactions with electron-rich molecules. By its incorporation into a MOF structure, most commonly combined with ZnI2, these properties are exploited and enhanced through the creation of "sticky" hydrophobic pores that absorb guest molecules via thermodynamic solvent-guest exchange, allowing equilibration of their positions through the porous framework.

elements.content: In order to expand the application of this technique, a range of MOFs are required in order to enable the study of a diverse range of natural products and biologically active molecules of varying size and functionality. Achieving a greater understanding of guest–host interactions will aid in the judicious selection of inorganic and organic moieties, potentially allowing the MOF hybrid architecture to be tailored to fulfill the demands of specific guest encapsulation, for example, allowing encapsulation of hydrophilic guests with varying steric requirements.
elements.clean_text: In order to expand the application of this technique, a range of MOFs are required in order to enable the study of a diverse range of natural products and biologically active molecules of varying size and functionality. Achieving a greater understanding of guest-host interactions will aid in the judicious selection of inorganic and organic moieties, potentially allowing the MOF hybrid architecture to be tailored to fulfill the demands of specific guest encapsulation, for example, allowing encapsulation of hydrophilic guests with varying steric requirements.

elements.content: Therefore, we present here a crystallographic study detailing the uptake and specific locations of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules within the crystalline sponge together with an analysis of possible guest–host interactions, something which has only been touched upon previously. As no systematic study has been reported previously, we hope to develop an understanding of the currently used crystalline sponge, its scope, and why it displays such unique properties.
elements.clean_text: Therefore, we present here a crystallographic study detailing the uptake and specific locations of a series of chemically related simple functionalized aromatic guest molecules within the crystalline sponge together with an analysis of possible guest-host interactions, something which has only been touched upon previously. As no systematic study has been reported previously, we hope to develop an understanding of the currently used crystalline sponge, its scope, and why it displays such unique properties.

elements.content: Before full publication of the preparative method for the crystalline MOF and the guest-uptake protocol outlined by Fujita and co-workers in their original Nature papers, a procedure was developed in-house involving the use of a nitrobenzene/1,2-dichlorobenzene solvent mixture for the dissolution of TPT. This resulted in the successful production of the desired crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2·(solvent)} n ] (1). Later, use of the simplified synthesis developed by Ramadhar et al. yielded good-quality single crystals with greater rapidity and reliability and with the more labile solvent CHCl3 in the pores, negating the need for solvent exchange before guest encapsulation. As a result, all of the crystals used in this study were synthesized by this method. However, a second crystalline Zn–TPT MOF with the formula [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2·CHCl3} n ] (2) () and a significantly smaller pore size () has been observed to form alongside the desired phase. Its fortuitously distinct crystal morphology () allows it to be easily identified and discarded before guest encapsulation. More recently, the formation of a third form was identified, having a morphology indistinguishable from the desired crystal but consistently giving a distinct set of unit cell parameters (). Although such crystals have not been obtained with sufficient quality to run full data analysis, they provide further evidence for the sensitivity of the experimental method and the challenge in its application. It is thought that these second and third forms arise from minor changes in temperature and humidity and variations in initial mixing during the layering process in the crystal synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Growth

Before full publication of the preparative method for the crystalline MOF and the guest-uptake protocol outlined by Fujita and co-workers in their original Nature papers, a procedure was developed in-house involving the use of a nitrobenzene/1,2-dichlorobenzene solvent mixture for the dissolution of TPT. This resulted in the successful production of the desired crystalline sponge [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2⋅(solvent)} n ] (1). Later, use of the simplified synthesis developed by Ramadhar et al. yielded good-quality single crystals with greater rapidity and reliability and with the more labile solvent CHCl3 in the pores, negating the need for solvent exchange before guest encapsulation. As a result, all of the crystals used in this study were synthesized by this method. However, a second crystalline Zn-TPT MOF with the formula [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2⋅CHCl3} n ] (2) () and a significantly smaller pore size () has been observed to form alongside the desired phase. Its fortuitously distinct crystal morphology () allows it to be easily identified and discarded before guest encapsulation. More recently, the formation of a third form was identified, having a morphology indistinguishable from the desired crystal but consistently giving a distinct set of unit cell parameters (). Although such crystals have not been obtained with sufficient quality to run full data analysis, they provide further evidence for the sensitivity of the experimental method and the challenge in its application. It is thought that these second and third forms arise from minor changes in temperature and humidity and variations in initial mixing during the layering process in the crystal synthesis.

elements.content: (a) Extended structure viewed down the c axis and (b) asymmetric unit cell of 2 obtained alongside the desired phase. TPT acts as an exotridentate ligand as in the original structure (1). Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% occupancy.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Extended structure viewed down the c axis and (b) asymmetric unit cell of 2 obtained alongside the desired phase. TPT acts as an exotridentate ligand as in the original structure (1). Thermal ellipsoids are shown at 50% occupancy.

elements.content: Micrographs of (a) a standard rod-shaped crystal of the desired Zn–TPT phase 1 and (b) (c) the two distinct characteristic morphologies of the novel Zn-TPT form 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Micrographs of (a) a standard rod-shaped crystal of the desired Zn-TPT phase 1 and (b) (c) the two distinct characteristic morphologies of the novel Zn-TPT form 2.

The manner in which guest molecules interact through their aromatic rings and functional groups was analyzed, and the extent to which the guests’ functionalization (rather than simply size) determines their interactions with the host framework and consequential ordering was explored. The simple organic aromatic guests encapsulated here were benzene (i), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (ii), 1,3-dichlorobenzene (iii), benzonitrile (iv), benzaldehyde (v), fluorobenzene (vi), and 1,4-difluorobenzene (vii) (). All are liquids at room temperature and miscible with chloroform, ensuring a high concentration gradient during encapsulation experiments and consequent high occupancy of the pores. All 11 guest–host complexes reported here are novel, although guest–host complexes of benzene and benzonitrile in an interpenetrated [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2·x(guest)} n ] framework have been reported previously (n.b.: when solvent molecules are present from the synthesis, they are not called gueststhis title is reserved only for molecules that have been purposefully encapsulated).
elements.clean_text:
Guest Encapsulation

The manner in which guest molecules interact through their aromatic rings and functional groups was analyzed, and the extent to which the guests' functionalization (rather than simply size) determines their interactions with the host framework and consequential ordering was explored. The simple organic aromatic guests encapsulated here were benzene (i), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (ii), 1,3-dichlorobenzene (iii), benzonitrile (iv), benzaldehyde (v), fluorobenzene (vi), and 1,4-difluorobenzene (vii) (). All are liquids at room temperature and miscible with chloroform, ensuring a high concentration gradient during encapsulation experiments and consequent high occupancy of the pores. All 11 guest-host complexes reported here are novel, although guest-host complexes of benzene and benzonitrile in an interpenetrated [{(ZnI2)3(TPT)2⋅x(guest)} n ] framework have been reported previously (n.b.: when solvent molecules are present from the synthesis, they are not called gueststhis title is reserved only for molecules that have been purposefully encapsulated).

elements.content: Molecules chosen for encapsulation in 1: benzene (i); 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (ii); 1,3-dichlorobenzene (iii); benzonitrile (iv); benzaldehyde (v); fluorobenzene (vi); 1,4-difluorobenzene (vii).
elements.clean_text: 3  Molecules chosen for encapsulation in 1: benzene (i); 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (ii); 1,3-dichlorobenzene (iii); benzonitrile (iv); benzaldehyde (v); fluorobenzene (vi); 1,4-difluorobenzene (vii).

elements.content: All of the guest–host complexes were found to crystallize in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c, showing a slight expansion in cell dimensions compared with the as-prepared crystalline sponge 1, as expected from the specific interactions and steric demands of our range of guests within the host structure. The ease of identification of the guest within the refined host framework varied according to the extent of disorder, as all displayed significant thermal motion and in some cases additional static and/or dynamic disorder. Solvent-accessible voids (SAVs) are present in the majority of structures discussed here and have been reported previously in encapsulation compounds of 1. Solvent masking techniques were not used in the analysis in order to maintain accurate chemical representations of the systems. However, the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON was employed to analyze the content of the voids (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: All of the guest-host complexes were found to crystallize in the centrosymmetric space group C2/c, showing a slight expansion in cell dimensions compared with the as-prepared crystalline sponge 1, as expected from the specific interactions and steric demands of our range of guests within the host structure. The ease of identification of the guest within the refined host framework varied according to the extent of disorder, as all displayed significant thermal motion and in some cases additional static and/or dynamic disorder. Solvent-accessible voids (SAVs) are present in the majority of structures discussed here and have been reported previously in encapsulation compounds of 1. Solvent masking techniques were not used in the analysis in order to maintain accurate chemical representations of the systems. However, the SQUEEZE routine in PLATON was employed to analyze the content of the voids (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: In order to reliably assess the interactions present in these guest–host complexes, we first set out to confirm that the guests consistently take up specific sites in the unit cell before seeking to determine the nature of guest–host interactions governing this positional specificity. Encapsulation experiments with the intended guests i, ii, iii, and iv were performed in duplicate, yielding encapsulation complexes with benzene (1i and 1i′), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii and 1ii′), 1,3-dichlorobenzene (1iii and 1iii′), and benzonitrile (1iv and 1iv′). Evaluating the crystallographic data by viewing the crystal structures down the b axis allows clear visualization of the different sites taken up by the guests within the infinite networks of solvent-accessible channels. It is clear that the guests consistently take up favorable positions and orientations specific (but not exclusive) to their type (). Guest molecules have been colored according to symmetry equivalence to allow facile comparison of crystal structures.
elements.clean_text:
Reproducibility

In order to reliably assess the interactions present in these guest-host complexes, we first set out to confirm that the guests consistently take up specific sites in the unit cell before seeking to determine the nature of guest-host interactions governing this positional specificity. Encapsulation experiments with the intended guests i, ii, iii, and iv were performed in duplicate, yielding encapsulation complexes with benzene (1i and 1i'), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii and 1ii'), 1,3-dichlorobenzene (1iii and 1iii'), and benzonitrile (1iv and 1iv'). Evaluating the crystallographic data by viewing the crystal structures down the b axis allows clear visualization of the different sites taken up by the guests within the infinite networks of solvent-accessible channels. It is clear that the guests consistently take up favorable positions and orientations specific (but not exclusive) to their type (). Guest molecules have been colored according to symmetry equivalence to allow facile comparison of crystal structures.

elements.content: Plots of the X-ray crystal structures of the encapsulation complexes analyzed in the reproducibility study, viewed down the b axis: benzene (a) 1i and (b) 1i′; 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (c) 1ii and (d) 1ii′; 1,2-dichlorobenzene (e) 1iii and (f) 1iii′; benzonitrile (g) 1iv and (h) 1iv′. Guest molecules are shown as ball-and-stick models with colors corresponding to equivalent sites. The framework is shown as a gray wireframe. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 4  Plots of the X-ray crystal structures of the encapsulation complexes analyzed in the reproducibility study, viewed down the b axis: benzene (a) 1i and (b) 1i'; 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (c) 1ii and (d) 1ii'; 1,2-dichlorobenzene (e) 1iii and (f) 1iii'; benzonitrile (g) 1iv and (h) 1iv'. Guest molecules are shown as ball-and-stick models with colors corresponding to equivalent sites. The framework is shown as a gray wireframe. Hydrogen atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The number and position of benzene molecules occupying the crystalline sponge show complete reproducibility (a,b), with five guest molecules (blue, purple, pink, dark green, and light green) taking up identical specific sites in each structure, along with one residual CHCl3 solvent molecule.
elements.clean_text:
Benzene (1i and 1i')

The number and position of benzene molecules occupying the crystalline sponge show complete reproducibility (a,b), with five guest molecules (blue, purple, pink, dark green, and light green) taking up identical specific sites in each structure, along with one residual CHCl3 solvent molecule.

elements.content: Similarly, the number and position of 4-fluorobenzaldehyde molecules occupying the crystalline sponge show complete reproducibility (c,d). Three guest molecules (red, blue, and green) take up identical specific sites in each structure.
elements.clean_text:
4-Fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii and 1ii')

Similarly, the number and position of 4-fluorobenzaldehyde molecules occupying the crystalline sponge show complete reproducibility (c,d). Three guest molecules (red, blue, and green) take up identical specific sites in each structure.

elements.content: In the case of 1,3-dichlorobenzene, the two independent encapsulation experiments yielded comparable results with five equivalent guest molecules present in both (e,f). The only distinguishing feature was rotational disorder of the “blue” guest molecule in 1iii′ (visualized as light and dark blue in f), leading to 50:50 occupancy of the site.
elements.clean_text:
1,3-Dichlorobenzene (1iii and 1iii')

In the case of 1,3-dichlorobenzene, the two independent encapsulation experiments yielded comparable results with five equivalent guest molecules present in both (e,f). The only distinguishing feature was rotational disorder of the "blue" guest molecule in 1iii' (visualized as light and dark blue in f), leading to 50:50 occupancy of the site.

elements.content: In the final comparison, the encapsulation of benzonitrile, the crystal structures show distinct similarities and some variation in guest position, as is evident by a comparison of g and h. Each structure has six distinct guest sites (with some residual CHCl3 solvent in 1iv), the majority of which are common to both structures; molecules positioned in such sites are colored dark blue, green, pink, red, and yellow. Within this subset, two instances of minor rotational disorder of the aromatic rings were observed, where both parts share approximately the same positions but variable orientation of the nitrile group (a). One instance is consistent between structures (light and dark green in g,h), while the second is seen only in 1iv (red and burgundy in g).
elements.clean_text:
Benzonitrile (1iv and 1iv')

In the final comparison, the encapsulation of benzonitrile, the crystal structures show distinct similarities and some variation in guest position, as is evident by a comparison of g and h. Each structure has six distinct guest sites (with some residual CHCl3 solvent in 1iv), the majority of which are common to both structures; molecules positioned in such sites are colored dark blue, green, pink, red, and yellow. Within this subset, two instances of minor rotational disorder of the aromatic rings were observed, where both parts share approximately the same positions but variable orientation of the nitrile group (a). One instance is consistent between structures (light and dark green in g,h), while the second is seen only in 1iv (red and burgundy in g).

elements.content: Two types of benzonitrile disorder observed in the unit cell of encapsulation compound 1iv: (a) rotational disorder within a specific site, resulting in variable orientation of the nitrile group; (b) significant displacement between two molecules disordered about the nitrile nitrogen atom. Atoms are shown as thermal ellipsoids at 50% probability.
elements.clean_text: 5  Two types of benzonitrile disorder observed in the unit cell of encapsulation compound 1iv: (a) rotational disorder within a specific site, resulting in variable orientation of the nitrile group; (b) significant displacement between two molecules disordered about the nitrile nitrogen atom. Atoms are shown as thermal ellipsoids at 50% probability.

elements.content: However, most significant for this study were the variations between structures 1iv and 1iv′ that relate to occupation of unique sites: (i) The molecule colored purple in 1iv′ (h, sitting on an inversion center) is unique to that structure. However, its occupancy is low (freely refined to 25%), in fact the lowest among all of the guest occupancies in this study. (ii) Uptake of unique sites but with certain overlap was observed in two cases, one being consistent between the two structures (light green and yellow) and one being confined to 1iv (pink and light blue). In this latter example, the two molecules in each pair share the terminal nitrogen atom of their nitrile group (see b). The significant disorder between the two components suggests relatively weak π···π interactions.
elements.clean_text: However, most significant for this study were the variations between structures 1iv and 1iv' that relate to occupation of unique sites: (i) The molecule colored purple in 1iv' (h, sitting on an inversion center) is unique to that structure. However, its occupancy is low (freely refined to 25%), in fact the lowest among all of the guest occupancies in this study. (ii) Uptake of unique sites but with certain overlap was observed in two cases, one being consistent between the two structures (light green and yellow) and one being confined to 1iv (pink and light blue). In this latter example, the two molecules in each pair share the terminal nitrogen atom of their nitrile group (see b). The significant disorder between the two components suggests relatively weak π⋅⋅⋅π interactions.

elements.content: From these four studies it is clear that there is reproducibility in the uptake of guests to specific sites within the unit cell of 1. The small variations observed between repeat encapsulation experiments are thought to be a result of marginal differences in external conditions. These may be experimental (e.g., variable interfacial mixing during the synthesis of 1), environmental (e.g., humidity and ambient temperature), and/or a result of refinement challenges (e.g., slight variations in crystal quality and size). Although care was taken to ensure that the conditions remained constant, minor variation must be expected unless impractical automation is usedsuch is the delicacy of the method. However, overall we can be confident that guest molecules preferentially take up specific sites and hence that multiple repetitions of the encapsulation procedure are not required in every case.
elements.clean_text: From these four studies it is clear that there is reproducibility in the uptake of guests to specific sites within the unit cell of 1. The small variations observed between repeat encapsulation experiments are thought to be a result of marginal differences in external conditions. These may be experimental (e.g., variable interfacial mixing during the synthesis of 1), environmental (e.g., humidity and ambient temperature), and/or a result of refinement challenges (e.g., slight variations in crystal quality and size). Although care was taken to ensure that the conditions remained constant, minor variation must be expected unless impractical automation is usedsuch is the delicacy of the method. However, overall we can be confident that guest molecules preferentially take up specific sites and hence that multiple repetitions of the encapsulation procedure are not required in every case.

elements.content: Packing diagrams showing the units cells of the encapsulation complexes with the guests benzene (1i), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii), benzaldehyde (1v), fluorobenzene (1vi), and 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii) as viewed down the b axis are displayed in . Guest molecules are colored by their symmetry equivalence within their own encapsulation complex and also their positional equivalence to guests in the other four structures. It is immediately apparent that certain positions within the unit cell are particularly favorable. A detailed examination of the packing diagrams and short contacts as defined in Mercury gives a clear indication of the dominant interactions. These are (i) electrostatic aromatic interactions (both CH···π and π···π), (ii) hydrogen bonding involving the aldehyde group or fluorine atom donors, and (iii) weaker, longer range van der Waals interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Guest Series

Packing diagrams showing the units cells of the encapsulation complexes with the guests benzene (1i), 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii), benzaldehyde (1v), fluorobenzene (1vi), and 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii) as viewed down the b axis are displayed in . Guest molecules are colored by their symmetry equivalence within their own encapsulation complex and also their positional equivalence to guests in the other four structures. It is immediately apparent that certain positions within the unit cell are particularly favorable. A detailed examination of the packing diagrams and short contacts as defined in Mercury gives a clear indication of the dominant interactions. These are (i) electrostatic aromatic interactions (both CH⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π), (ii) hydrogen bonding involving the aldehyde group or fluorine atom donors, and (iii) weaker, longer range van der Waals interactions.

elements.content: Unit cells of the X-ray crystal structures of encapsulation complexes, viewed down the b axis: (a) benzene (1i); (b) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (c) benzaldehyde (1v); (d) fluorobenzene (1vi); (e) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii). The coloring of the guest molecules indicates positional equivalence both within each structure and among the five structures.
elements.clean_text: 6  Unit cells of the X-ray crystal structures of encapsulation complexes, viewed down the b axis: (a) benzene (1i); (b) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (c) benzaldehyde (1v); (d) fluorobenzene (1vi); (e) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii). The coloring of the guest molecules indicates positional equivalence both within each structure and among the five structures.

elements.content: Looking across the series it is evident that the positions guest molecules take up within the pores of 1 do vary with the variation in functionality, but not in every case. One specific position has been identified as common to all five guest species, observable in by the blue-colored guest molecules. In this instance the molecules generally adopt a perpendicular y-shaped arrangement with the pyridine ring of the framework. The length of the CH···π interaction varies (see ), as expected from the subtle variation in orientation observed in the crystal structures. While the guest molecules in 1i, 1ii, 1v, and 1vi sit at broadly similar distances and orientations to the framework, interacting with only one pyridine ring, the 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules in 1vii are sufficiently displaced to interact with two. This difference is visualized in , which shows the contrasting positions of benzaldehyde and 1,4-difluorobenzene in relation to the section of the framework with which they interact. Furthermore, the guests appear to be stabilized by several interactions between both hydrogen and non-hydrogen ring substituents and the triazide or pyridine rings of the host.
elements.clean_text: Looking across the series it is evident that the positions guest molecules take up within the pores of 1 do vary with the variation in functionality, but not in every case. One specific position has been identified as common to all five guest species, observable in  by the blue-colored guest molecules. In this instance the molecules generally adopt a perpendicular y-shaped arrangement with the pyridine ring of the framework. The length of the CH⋅⋅⋅π interaction varies (see ), as expected from the subtle variation in orientation observed in the crystal structures. While the guest molecules in 1i, 1ii, 1v, and 1vi sit at broadly similar distances and orientations to the framework, interacting with only one pyridine ring, the 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules in 1vii are sufficiently displaced to interact with two. This difference is visualized in , which shows the contrasting positions of benzaldehyde and 1,4-difluorobenzene in relation to the section of the framework with which they interact. Furthermore, the guests appear to be stabilized by several interactions between both hydrogen and non-hydrogen ring substituents and the triazide or pyridine rings of the host.

elements.content: (a) Perpendicular y-shaped interaction of benzaldehyde and the host framework in 1v, which is also representative of interactions in 1ii and 1vi. (b) Offset y-shaped interaction of 1,4-difluorobenzene in 1vii.
elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Perpendicular y-shaped interaction of benzaldehyde and the host framework in 1v, which is also representative of interactions in 1ii and 1vi. (b) Offset y-shaped interaction of 1,4-difluorobenzene in 1vii.

elements.content:
Parameters Used To Describe the CH···π Interactions in Structures <bold>1i</bold>, <bold>1ii</bold>, <bold>1v</bold>, <bold>1vi</bold>, and <bold>1vii</bold> between the Centroids of the “Blue” Guest Molecules and the Hydrogen Substituents of the Framework in Closest Proximity lengths/Å angles/deg guest structure 1 2 3 α β benzene 1i 4.83 3.28 3.16 119.69 123.91 4-fluorobenzaldehyde 1ii 5.46 3.86 3.56 125.18 137.91 benzaldehyde 1v 4.91 3.41 3.01 118.64 135.76 fluorobenzene 1vi 5.14 3.75 3.17 116.04 141.69 1,4-difluorobenzene 1vii 5.57 4.36 3.54 111.28 146.97 1,4-difluorobenzene 1vii 5.43 4.20 3.46 110.99 140.80

The lengths and angles are defined in Figure .

Two sites in the unit cell have been identified as common to four of the five guest species irrespective of functionalization. These are identified in by red (found in structures 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii) and dark green (in 1i, 1ii, 1v, and 1vi) colored guest molecules. In both cases, while the position and inclination of the aromatic ring are broadly the same, the orientation of the functional group varies.
elements.clean_text: Two sites in the unit cell have been identified as common to four of the five guest species irrespective of functionalization. These are identified in  by red (found in structures 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii) and dark green (in 1i, 1ii, 1v, and 1vi) colored guest molecules. In both cases, while the position and inclination of the aromatic ring are broadly the same, the orientation of the functional group varies.

elements.content: The interactions governing the positioning of guests colored dark green are broadly similar to those discussed above in the “blue” site: y-shaped CH···π interactions between the guest and a framework pyridine ring. Analysis of the contact distances showed that fluorobenzene and benzene in 1i and 1vi are positioned almost identically, as are fluorobenzaldehyde and benzaldehyde in 1ii and 1v (see Table S1). Contact measurements revealed the presence of C­(H)O···HCpyridine interactions in the latter pair (2.64 and 2.89 Å for 1ii and 1v, respectively), which are thought to be the cause of their relatively offset orientation.
elements.clean_text: The interactions governing the positioning of guests colored dark green are broadly similar to those discussed above in the "blue" site: y-shaped CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions between the guest and a framework pyridine ring. Analysis of the contact distances showed that fluorobenzene and benzene in 1i and 1vi are positioned almost identically, as are fluorobenzaldehyde and benzaldehyde in 1ii and 1v (see Table S1). Contact measurements revealed the presence of C(H)O⋅⋅⋅HCpyridine interactions in the latter pair (2.64 and 2.89 Å for 1ii and 1v, respectively), which are thought to be the cause of their relatively offset orientation.

elements.content: The guests indicated by red coloration in structures 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii () engage in face-to-face π···π interactions with the pyridine ring that separates the two distinct chambers in the crystalline sponge. As benzene is not seen to take up this position, evidence suggests that the formation of this π···π interaction is facilitated by the presence of the substituent groups. This can be rationalized by considering that the electron-withdrawing nature of the −C­(O)H and −F functional groups (relative to −H in benzene) favors a face-to-face π···π arrangement with the electron-deficient framework. Interestingly, however, the identity of the guests’ substituent groups does not obviously affect the magnitude of this π···π interaction, as determined by the intermolecular centroid–centroid distances of 3.72, 3.69, 3.79, and 3.78 Å for 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii, respectively, with all of the dihedral angles between the mean planes of the guest and host rings being <13°.
elements.clean_text: The guests indicated by red coloration in structures 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii () engage in face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions with the pyridine ring that separates the two distinct chambers in the crystalline sponge. As benzene is not seen to take up this position, evidence suggests that the formation of this π⋅⋅⋅π interaction is facilitated by the presence of the substituent groups. This can be rationalized by considering that the electron-withdrawing nature of the -C(O)H and -F functional groups (relative to -H in benzene) favors a face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π arrangement with the electron-deficient framework. Interestingly, however, the identity of the guests' substituent groups does not obviously affect the magnitude of this π⋅⋅⋅π interaction, as determined by the intermolecular centroid-centroid distances of 3.72, 3.69, 3.79, and 3.78 Å for 1ii, 1v, 1vi, and 1vii, respectively, with all of the dihedral angles between the mean planes of the guest and host rings being <13°.

elements.content: However, the guest functionality does affect the orientation of the molecules as a result of different weak interactions with the surrounding framework. shows the guests in this position, highlighting their common face-to-face interaction with the pyridine ring of the framework but varied orientation. Substituents involved in this guest–host interaction are oriented toward the pyridine and triazide rings of TPT rather than into the empty void space of the pores. The orientations of benzaldehyde and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde are determined through (O)­CH···Ntriazide hydrogen bonds (short contacts of 2.84 and 2.54 Å, respectively), with the fluorine atom present in the latter yielding no significant short-contact interactions with the framework. This is unsurprising as the C–F group competes unfavorably with aldehyde groups with regard to hydrogen-bond formation. There is, however, the suggestion of weak Fred···Fred interactions (3.14 Å) between symmetrically equivalent guests.
elements.clean_text: However, the guest functionality does affect the orientation of the molecules as a result of different weak interactions with the surrounding framework.  shows the guests in this position, highlighting their common face-to-face interaction with the pyridine ring of the framework but varied orientation. Substituents involved in this guest-host interaction are oriented toward the pyridine and triazide rings of TPT rather than into the empty void space of the pores. The orientations of benzaldehyde and 4-fluorobenzaldehyde are determined through (O)CH⋅⋅⋅Ntriazide hydrogen bonds (short contacts of 2.84 and 2.54 Å, respectively), with the fluorine atom present in the latter yielding no significant short-contact interactions with the framework. This is unsurprising as the C-F group competes unfavorably with aldehyde groups with regard to hydrogen-bond formation. There is, however, the suggestion of weak Fred⋅⋅⋅Fred interactions (3.14 Å) between symmetrically equivalent guests.

elements.content: Face-to-face π···π interactions in the encapsulation complexes between the aromatic ring of the guest molecule and a pyridine ring at a common site within the unit cell: (a) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (b) benzaldehyde (1v); (c) fluorobenzene (1vi), with rotational disorder shown (F1a and F1b occur with 50% occupancy); (d) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii), with the fluorine atoms labeled to distinguish them. Centroids are shown as red spheres and intercentroid contacts as cyan lines.
elements.clean_text: 8  Face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the encapsulation complexes between the aromatic ring of the guest molecule and a pyridine ring at a common site within the unit cell: (a) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (b) benzaldehyde (1v); (c) fluorobenzene (1vi), with rotational disorder shown (F1a and F1b occur with 50% occupancy); (d) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii), with the fluorine atoms labeled to distinguish them. Centroids are shown as red spheres and intercentroid contacts as cyan lines.

elements.content: In the case of fluorobenzene (1vi) (c), the fluorine atom takes up a similar position as the absent aldehyde group, interacting with the equivalent part of the framework albeit with longer contact distance (F1a···Ntriazide, 3.11 Å). There is also a comparable interaction with a carbon atom in the same triazide ring (F1a···Ctriazide, 3.13 Å). Similarly, the closest contacts of the fluorine substituent on the equivalent 1,4-fluorobenzene guest in 1vii are F2···Ctriazide (3.16 Å) and F2···Ntriazide (3.26 Å). Analysis of the fluorine atom para to this (F3) yielded no significant short contact measurements with the framework, but as in 1ii there is the suggestion of guest–guest Fred···Fred interactions (3.39 Å). It is important to note that the interaction of fluorine is sufficiently weak in fluorobenzene (1vi) for disorder to occur with 50:50 occupancy of two positions (c). The interaction determining this second orientation appears to be F1b···HCpyridine with an intermolecular distance of 2.78 Å. This distance is greater than the sum of the van der Waals radii of fluorine and hydrogen and in the range of a weak hydrogen bond.
elements.clean_text: In the case of fluorobenzene (1vi) (c), the fluorine atom takes up a similar position as the absent aldehyde group, interacting with the equivalent part of the framework albeit with longer contact distance (F1a⋅⋅⋅Ntriazide, 3.11 Å). There is also a comparable interaction with a carbon atom in the same triazide ring (F1a⋅⋅⋅Ctriazide, 3.13 Å). Similarly, the closest contacts of the fluorine substituent on the equivalent 1,4-fluorobenzene guest in 1vii are F2⋅⋅⋅Ctriazide (3.16 Å) and F2⋅⋅⋅Ntriazide (3.26 Å). Analysis of the fluorine atom para to this (F3) yielded no significant short contact measurements with the framework, but as in 1ii there is the suggestion of guest-guest Fred⋅⋅⋅Fred interactions (3.39 Å). It is important to note that the interaction of fluorine is sufficiently weak in fluorobenzene (1vi) for disorder to occur with 50:50 occupancy of two positions (c). The interaction determining this second orientation appears to be F1b⋅⋅⋅HCpyridine with an intermolecular distance of 2.78 Å. This distance is greater than the sum of the van der Waals radii of fluorine and hydrogen and in the range of a weak hydrogen bond.

elements.content: There are other positions within the unit cell that are taken up by more than one of the guests in the series, i.e., sites indicated by yellow-colored guests in 1v and 1vi (c,d, respectively) and purple-colored guests in 1i and 1v (a,c, respectively). However, there are instances where guest molecules take up positions either favored by a minority or novel to their species alone. This latter variation can be found in structure 1vii with two positions identified as novel to this encapsulation complex, shown in e as occupied by light-blue- and light-green-colored 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules. Interestingly, those guests colored light green would appear to be stabilized by interactions with multiple framework pyridine rings through both π···π interactions (intercentroid distance of 3.93 Å and dihedral angle of 10.24°) and CH···π interactions (CH···centroidpyridine, 3.43 Å; dihedral angle, 74.21°). Those molecules colored light blue are stabilized by π···CH interactions with one pyridine ring (centroid···HCpyridine, 3.48 Å; dihedral angle, 56.54°) and F···H interactions with a second ring (CF···HCpyridine, 2.69 Å). The question still remains, however, as to why only 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules take up these positions, and the answer may come down to guest–guest interactions. There is evidence for the formation of two Hgreen···Fpink interactions (3.13 and 3.18 Å) and an Flight‑green···Flight‑green interaction (3.78 Å) that may aid in the stabilization and ordering of 1,4-difluorobenzene in these positions. Additionally, an Flight‑green···Hred interaction at 2.50 Å is evidence for fluorine–hydrogen bonds between guest molecules.
elements.clean_text: There are other positions within the unit cell that are taken up by more than one of the guests in the series, i.e., sites indicated by yellow-colored guests in 1v and 1vi (c,d, respectively) and purple-colored guests in 1i and 1v (a,c, respectively). However, there are instances where guest molecules take up positions either favored by a minority or novel to their species alone. This latter variation can be found in structure 1vii with two positions identified as novel to this encapsulation complex, shown in e as occupied by light-blue- and light-green-colored 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules. Interestingly, those guests colored light green would appear to be stabilized by interactions with multiple framework pyridine rings through both π⋅⋅⋅π interactions (intercentroid distance of 3.93 Å and dihedral angle of 10.24°) and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions (CH⋅⋅⋅centroidpyridine, 3.43 Å; dihedral angle, 74.21°). Those molecules colored light blue are stabilized by π⋅⋅⋅CH interactions with one pyridine ring (centroid⋅⋅⋅HCpyridine, 3.48 Å; dihedral angle, 56.54°) and F⋅⋅⋅H interactions with a second ring (CF⋅⋅⋅HCpyridine, 2.69 Å). The question still remains, however, as to why only 1,4-difluorobenzene molecules take up these positions, and the answer may come down to guest-guest interactions. There is evidence for the formation of two Hgreen⋅⋅⋅Fpink interactions (3.13 and 3.18 Å) and an Flight-green⋅⋅⋅Flight-green interaction (3.78 Å) that may aid in the stabilization and ordering of 1,4-difluorobenzene in these positions. Additionally, an Flight-green⋅⋅⋅Hred interaction at 2.50 Å is evidence for fluorine-hydrogen bonds between guest molecules.

elements.content: Through the encapsulation of simple organic aromatic guests into the crystalline sponge, we were able to show that guest molecules consistently take up specific sites within the unit cell, albeit with minor variations in orientation and disorder. Measurement of guest–host and guest–guest interactions confirmed that π···π and CH···π interactions persist throughout the structure, and we can be confident of their dominant role in the ability of the crystalline sponge to render the guest molecules regularly ordered. Nevertheless, certain guests have unique interactions according to their functionality, such as hydrogen bonds that contribute to both the position and specific orientation of the molecules. We believe that an understanding of the dominant interactions formed between guest molecules and the host framework is vital to understanding how this crystalline sponge renders guest molecules regularly ordered. We believe that it can aid in the systematic design of the alternative structures required to enable the encapsulation of a greater variety of guests than is currently possible. This is likely to include larger, more complex molecules as well as those with different combinations of functional groups.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Through the encapsulation of simple organic aromatic guests into the crystalline sponge, we were able to show that guest molecules consistently take up specific sites within the unit cell, albeit with minor variations in orientation and disorder. Measurement of guest-host and guest-guest interactions confirmed that π⋅⋅⋅π and CH⋅⋅⋅π interactions persist throughout the structure, and we can be confident of their dominant role in the ability of the crystalline sponge to render the guest molecules regularly ordered. Nevertheless, certain guests have unique interactions according to their functionality, such as hydrogen bonds that contribute to both the position and specific orientation of the molecules. We believe that an understanding of the dominant interactions formed between guest molecules and the host framework is vital to understanding how this crystalline sponge renders guest molecules regularly ordered. We believe that it can aid in the systematic design of the alternative structures required to enable the encapsulation of a greater variety of guests than is currently possible. This is likely to include larger, more complex molecules as well as those with different combinations of functional groups.

elements.content: [{(ZnI2)3(tris­(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2·x(CHCl3)} n ] was prepared following the procedure reported in the literature. For guest encapsulation, the mother liquor was reduced to the minimum volume while still covering the crystals, and the guest liquid (∼1 cm3) was pipetted in. After a specific number of days (5–7; see Table S2) of incubation at ∼22 °C, suitable rod- or block-shaped crystals were selected and subjected to SCXRD. Crystals used for repeat experiments came from different batches.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Crystalline Sponge Synthesis and Guest Encapsulation

[{(ZnI2)3(tris(4-pyridyl)-1,3,5-triazine)2⋅x(CHCl3)} n ] was prepared following the procedure reported in the literature. For guest encapsulation, the mother liquor was reduced to the minimum volume while still covering the crystals, and the guest liquid (~1 cm3) was pipetted in. After a specific number of days (5-7; see Table S2) of incubation at ~22 °C, suitable rod- or block-shaped crystals were selected and subjected to SCXRD. Crystals used for repeat experiments came from different batches.

elements.content: Crystals were placed in Fomblin, and single crystals were selected and mounted onto nylon loops. X-ray diffraction data were recorded on an Agilent Super Nova dual diffractometer (Agilent Technologies Inc., Santa Clara, CA) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 150 K. Unit cell determination, data reduction, and absorption corrections were carried out using CrysAlisPro. The structures were solved with the Sir2004 structure solution program by direct methods or Superflip and refined by full-matrix least-squares on the basis of F 2 using SHELX 2013 within the OLEX2 graphical user interface. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were included using a riding model. Details of the treatment of individual guest molecules can be found in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Procedures

Crystals were placed in Fomblin, and single crystals were selected and mounted onto nylon loops. X-ray diffraction data were recorded on an Agilent Super Nova dual diffractometer (Agilent Technologies Inc., Santa Clara, CA) with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) at 150 K. Unit cell determination, data reduction, and absorption corrections were carried out using CrysAlisPro. The structures were solved with the Sir2004 structure solution program by direct methods or Superflip and refined by full-matrix least-squares on the basis of F 2 using SHELX 2013 within the OLEX2 graphical user interface. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were included using a riding model. Details of the treatment of individual guest molecules can be found in the Supporting Information.

cln_elements.content: Two types of benzonitrile disorder observed in the unit cell of encapsulation compound 1iv: (a) rotational disorder within a specific site, resulting in variable orientation of the nitrile group; (b) significant displacement between two molecules disordered about the nitrile nitrogen atom. Atoms are shown as thermal ellipsoids at 50% probability.
cln_elements.clean_text: 5  Two types of benzonitrile disorder observed in the unit cell of encapsulation compound 1iv: (a) rotational disorder within a specific site, resulting in variable orientation of the nitrile group; (b) significant displacement between two molecules disordered about the nitrile nitrogen atom. Atoms are shown as thermal ellipsoids at 50% probability.

cln_elements.content: Unit cells of the X-ray crystal structures of encapsulation complexes, viewed down the b axis: (a) benzene (1i); (b) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (c) benzaldehyde (1v); (d) fluorobenzene (1vi); (e) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii). The coloring of the guest molecules indicates positional equivalence both within each structure and among the five structures.
cln_elements.clean_text: 6  Unit cells of the X-ray crystal structures of encapsulation complexes, viewed down the b axis: (a) benzene (1i); (b) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (c) benzaldehyde (1v); (d) fluorobenzene (1vi); (e) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii). The coloring of the guest molecules indicates positional equivalence both within each structure and among the five structures.

cln_elements.content: (a) Perpendicular y-shaped interaction of benzaldehyde and the host framework in 1v, which is also representative of interactions in 1ii and 1vi. (b) Offset y-shaped interaction of 1,4-difluorobenzene in 1vii.
cln_elements.clean_text: 7  (a) Perpendicular y-shaped interaction of benzaldehyde and the host framework in 1v, which is also representative of interactions in 1ii and 1vi. (b) Offset y-shaped interaction of 1,4-difluorobenzene in 1vii.

cln_elements.content: Face-to-face π···π interactions in the encapsulation complexes between the aromatic ring of the guest molecule and a pyridine ring at a common site within the unit cell: (a) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (b) benzaldehyde (1v); (c) fluorobenzene (1vi), with rotational disorder shown (F1a and F1b occur with 50% occupancy); (d) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii), with the fluorine atoms labeled to distinguish them. Centroids are shown as red spheres and intercentroid contacts as cyan lines.
cln_elements.clean_text: 8  Face-to-face π⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the encapsulation complexes between the aromatic ring of the guest molecule and a pyridine ring at a common site within the unit cell: (a) 4-fluorobenzaldehyde (1ii); (b) benzaldehyde (1v); (c) fluorobenzene (1vi), with rotational disorder shown (F1a and F1b occur with 50% occupancy); (d) 1,4-difluorobenzene (1vii), with the fluorine atoms labeled to distinguish them. Centroids are shown as red spheres and intercentroid contacts as cyan lines.

metadata.title:
The Crystalline Sponge Method: A Systematic Study
of the Reproducibility of Simple Aromatic Molecule Encapsulation and
Guest–Host Interactions
